text: Definitely joined this group at the right time! I am making some decisions about my career and kind of feel pressure to choose between two things I don't necessarily want (although having choices is certainly better than the alternative). Both kind of still feel like settling to me, though. Could use some advice! (Making this a thread to minimize real estate on here)

elements.text: Definitely joined this group at the right time! I am making some decisions about my career and kind of feel pressure to choose between two things I don't necessarily want (although having choices is certainly better than the alternative). text: I have been interviewing with a company for a while. A recruiter reached out to me on LinkedIn and  I've been through the entire interview process. They offered the role to someone else, but she declined and took another offer. This company is back to chatting with me. They have reposted this job several times over the past month. My gut feeling is telling me that they are extremely picky and maybe even a bit unsure of what they want. I feel like there are plenty of candidates available and more appropriate in terms of experience, so I'm judging them slightly for even continuing the process with me (like, you don't need to settle. We live in a major city, theres plenty of talent). The role gives me some opportunities I dont have in my current position (more senior title, nice pay bump, some management experience). They've also been very nice on the calls.

text: In my current role, I am the only marketer. My colleague just left, so I'm alone now. My ideas are not heard, although they like my work and definitely do not want me to leave. I've been there about 2 years and plan to, regardless, but I know the position is safe and the company is profitable. In spite of not wanting to work there, I am not desperate to leave and the new company doesn't have me wildly enthusiastic about it. Performance reviews are in a couple of weeks and I plan to ask for a raise/ promotion which I expect I will get (on some level). I would do this regardless of what happens with the other job.

Performance reviews are in a couple of weeks and I plan to ask for a raise/ promotion which I expect I will get (on some level). I would do this regardless of what happens with the other job.

text: My question for the group is more related to... what do I do if I get this offer? In all honesty, these are both startup companies and I want to get out of that space. I suspect I could get a light promotion (not as much as I'd make at the new role, though) and wait it out at my current company for a few more months for a position I'm more excited about. Alternatively, I am not really learning things or becoming a better marketer here. The unknown of the other job is a little scary, but comes with possibility. If it doesn't work out, I will be in a better spot to get another senior type of role (and have that management experience). If anyone has experience or advice for navigating, I'd really appreciate it! (Sorry for the walls of text)

text: "I feel like there are plenty of candidates available and more appropriate in terms of experience, so I'm judging them slightly for even continuing the process with me (like, you don't need to settle. We live in a major city, theres plenty of talent)." <-- this is classic impostor syndrome (I would know). Don't sell yourself short! They wouldn't be continuing to talk with you if they didn't think you'd bring something to the team! I'd just continue with the process until you get an offer, you don't need to make any decisions until then and it wouldn't do any harm. Sorry I gotta run so I can't speak to the rest of your comments but I just wanted to pitch in with that real quick

text: Thanks <@U0113AV4895>! Rapid response and definitely correct about the imposter syndrome. I am so suspicious lol.

elements.text: ! Rapid response and definitely correct about the imposter syndrome. I am so suspicious lol.

text:
Based on what you've said, I would say just hold off on switching until you feel more 100% about a job. If you know you want to move out of the startup space, I suspect you may feel like you're ready to switch as soon as you get this new job anyway if you already know you want to go in a different direction.

Additionally, it does seem odd to me that they offered it to someone else and then are still hiring while looking at you... have you asked them why they originally offered the position to someone else? it might be worth just having a frank conversation with them regarding their expectations for the role to make sure you know exactly what you're getting into

text: <@ULJBEFSJJ> oh yeah, they mentioned that this other person declined because she accepted another offer elsewhere. She apparently had a bit more experience than me in some areas they really want to focus on (brand awareness campaigns). The continuous listing for the job is weird though and I didn't ask them about that part. Good idea

text: Does the new company have better name recognition, or is it perceived as more prestigious? If Y, and you'd get the perks you mentioned, I would definitely consider it. If nothing else, it can be a stepping stone to the next role, or get you on the road to being an executive (if that's what you want). What stood out to me is you saying you're not really learning anything at your current gig. You deserve an opportunity where you're growing and being challenged!

text: <@UJFELMVU1> yeah! I definitely want to move on from my current company either way! It's not my forever home. Unfortunately neither of these companies is anything recognizable lol. I was slightly concerned that I'll be leading the marketing department in the new role and not have any mentorship within the company, but I guess thats what is happening at my current one too now so perhaps not worth worrying about that. (And I've got great communities like this!)

text: The whole "being an executive" thing is an entirely separate conversation. I want to try managing people (in their careers, not just freelancers and interns) to see if its for me, so I am hopeful to have at least one direct report wherever I go. I do really enjoy wordsmithing and executing, but feel like becoming a better specialist isn't translating into respect or income for the work, its just raising the bar on what it means to be a content marketer. It's not enough to master an area of content, like web copy or something. You also need to be a designer, script-writer, podcast host, video editor, social media personality, and product subject matter expert. Which I would be fine with because learning and improving is cool, but it's also a little exhausting to never catch the carrot so to speak.

text: I feel all of that! Perhaps as <@ULJBEFSJJ> said, now is a good time to not make any big moves. You could plot out what you're looking for (and be honest with yourself in the areas where you're just not sure). I took some time to do this a while ago, using just a Google Doc, internet research, and some calls with people in my network. It was amazingly helpful and made me feel more in control of my career, even though I didn't have all the answers.

text: During your conversations with this new company, have you brought up what kind of mentorship opportunities would be available? Is the opportunity to manage others and the pay bump compelling enough to want you to move jobs if you're looking to get out of the startup world?

elements.text: During your conversations with this new company, have you brought up what kind of mentorship opportunities would be available? Is the opportunity to manage others and the pay bump compelling enough to want you to move jobs if you're looking to get out of the startup world?

text: <@U0166H7KUAZ> the CEO has a marketing coach, I guess, that he meets with regularly (the CEO's background is in finance but he's interested in marketing). He suggested that if I had someone or something like that that I wanted to explore it would be an option. Very amenable to growth and hiring people/ getting the right resources based on what he's told me so far.
